candidates.title: Issue 267: Remove runtime drop error message
candidates.body:
**Change log description**

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #267 #308 #253

**What the code does**  
ClientFactory is the only place that contains the Runtime and it cannot be cloned, so there is only one place that's holding the runtime now.
Make another struct ClientFacotryAsync that holds `Runtime::Handle`, which can be cloned and used in async context.

**How to verify it**  
Test should pass

candidates.title: Issue 232: Create command line app which reads from stdin and publishes to Pravega
candidates.body:
**Change log description**  
- Command line app which reads from stdin and publishes it to the configured Pravega Stream.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fixes #232

**What the code does**  

Implements a command-line app that reads from stdin and publishes it to the configured Pravega Stream.
```
cat ./event.log | ./pravegctl write scope1/stream1
```

App capabilities
```
PravegaCtl 0.0.1
Utility to interact with Pravega

USAGE:
    pravegactl [FLAGS] [OPTIONS] <SUBCOMMAND>

FLAGS:
    -a, --enable-auth    Enable authorization, default is false
    -h, --help           Prints help information
    -V, --version        Prints version information

OPTIONS:
    -u, --controller-uri <controller-uri>    To enable TLS use uri of the format tls://ip:port [default:
                                             tcp://127.0.0.1:9090]

SUBCOMMANDS:
    create-scope            Create Scope
    create-stream           Create Stream with a fixed segment count
    help                    Prints this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)
    list-scopes             List Scopes
    list-streams            List Streams under a scope
    list-streams-for-tag    List Streams for a tag, under a scope
    write                   Write events from STDIN. Each line is treated as an individual event

```

Update the workflow to generate artifacts for the following targets
* x86_64-unknown-linux-musl
* arm-unknown-linux-gnueabihf
* x86_64-apple-darwin
* x86_64-pc-windows-msvc
* x86_64-pc-windows-gnu
* i686-pc-windows-msvc

The generated artifacts are uploaded to the workflow run. e.g: https://github.com/pravega/pravega-client-rust/actions/runs/1089026393#artifacts


**How to verify it**  
All the existing tests should continue to pass.

candidates.title: Issue 234: Implement index stream
candidates.body:
**Change log description**  
Add support to the index stream.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #234 

**What the code does**  
***Naming***
* Record: Fixed size(4KB) event written to the stream. A record contains: type code(4 bytes), entries length(4 bytes), data length(4 bytes) entries, entries and data.
* Field: A key value pair(&'static str, u64) . Key is a string that user defines, value is a u64 that is monotonically increasing.
* Fields: A set of field. User specifies a label struct that has a number of fields, the name of the field is the entry key and the value is entry value. This impl provides a procedure macro called label that can parse the struct to an array of entries. 

***Index writer***:
* append(data, label): append the given label and data to the stream. It is guaranteed that the new label has all the exsiting entries and their values are not less than the current values.
* append_conditionally(data, label, condition_label): same as above, plus a given condition label that has to be exactly the same as the latest label in the stream
* flush(): flush appends
* truncate(offset): truncate to a offset.

***Index reader***:
* search_offset(entry: (key, value)): search for the offset of the first record that has a matching key and value that is equal to or larger than the target value 
* read(start_offset, end_offset): read a slice of a stream. When end_offset is u64::MAX, it means tail read.
* first_record(): first readable record
* last_record(): latest record
* head_offset():
* last_offset():


**How to verify it**  
Tests should pass.

candidates.title: Issue 256:  Enable stream tag API on the RUST client.
candidates.body:
**Change log description**  
- Enable Stream Tag API on the RUST client.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fixes #256 

**What the code does**  
- Update the Controller proto file with the latest version of the Controller.
- Enable Tag related APIs on the RUST client.
The following APIs have been enabled.

```rust

    /**
     * API to fetch the Stream Configuration of a Stream.
     */
    async fn get_stream_configuration(&self, stream: &ScopedStream) -> ResultRetry<StreamConfiguration>;

    /**
     * API to fetch the Tags for a Stream.
     */
    async fn get_stream_tags(&self, stream: &ScopedStream) -> ResultRetry<Option<Vec<String>>>;

    /**
     * API to list streams associated with the given tag under a given scope and continuation token.
     * Use the pravega_controller_client::paginator::list_streams_for_tag to paginate over all the streams.
     */
    async fn list_streams_for_tag(
        &self,
        scope: &Scope,
        tag: &str,
        token: &CToken,
    ) -> ResultRetry<Option<(Vec<ScopedStream>, CToken)>>;
```
- Enable CLI option to create Stream with tags and list streams with a tag under a given scope.
```
osboxes@osboxes:~$ ./controller-cli list-streams-for-tag --help
controller-cli-list-streams-for-tag 0.2.0
List Streams for a tag, under a scope

USAGE:
    controller-cli list-streams-for-tag <scope-name> <tag>

FLAGS:
    -h, --help       Prints help information
    -V, --version    Prints version information

ARGS:
    <scope-name>    Scope Name
    <tag>           Tag Name

```


**How to verify it**  
All the existing and newly added tests should pass.
Integration tests have been created to run against the latest version of Pravega.

candidates.title: Issue 247: Accept scheme in controller URI
candidates.body:
**Change log description**  
* allow scheme to be included in PravegaNodeUri
* changes ClientConfigBuilder to automatically set `is_tls_enabled = true` when uri scheme is 'tls'
* allows tls scheme to be used with StreamManager Python client when tls_enabled default value (false) is used

**Purpose of the change**  

Fixes #247 

**What the code does**  
changes to shared/lib
* accepts schemes in PravegaNodeUri
* added PravegaNodeUriParseError
* added PravegaNodeUri::is_well_formed static method
* added PravegaNodeUri::uri_parts_from_string static method
* changed existing methods to use uri_parts_from_string

changes to config/lib
* added default builder for `ClientConfigBuilder::is_tls_enabled`
* altered `ClientConfigBuilder::extract_trustcerts` to also call `default_is_tls_enabled` (builder order of operations calls extract_trustcerts before default_is_tls_enabled)
* added `ClientConfigBuilder::validate` to check for conflicts between uri scheme and `.is_tls_enabled()`
* removed duplicate `builder(setter(into))`  from controller_uri because its already set at the struct level

changes to python_binding/stream_manager
* changed `StreamManager` constructor, if `tls_enabled = false` then rely on the scheme from `controller_uri` to set `is_tls_enabled`
* updated sample usage


**How to verify it**  

* rust tests have been added 
* was not able to test python changes due to issues with maturin

**Comments**

The only uri scheme this code specifically tests for is `tls`. It should probably only allow `tcp, tls` schemes (but see my outstanding question on #247)

Some existing PravegaNodeUri methods panic if the uri is malformed. I added `is_well_formed` static method so that library consumers could test a uri before building a clientconfig.  This approach seems a bit dodgy. Perhaps changing PravegaNodeUri to a struct not derived from String could improve this, but I think that would require more changes to the library.

If we want true backwards compatibility with the python client, we may wish to change StreamManager `tls_enabled` arg to `PyAny` type, then set the default python arg to either `None` or a sentinel object that can make it clear whether or not the python caller provided a value for `tls_enabled`

This is my first rust code. Some of the changes don't look quite right. I considered using Regex but its currently only used in the auth crate, so didn't seem worth pulling into this one.

candidates.title: Issue 243, 244: Support multiple certs and allow user to pass keycloak as json string
candidates.body:
**Change log description**  
1. `ClientConfig` can now take multiple certs. Users cam put certs in a directory and pass that directory to the `ClientConfig`.
2. User can now pass keycloak json string directly to the `ClientConfig` by using `Credentials::keycloak_by_json_string(json);`

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #243 #244 

**What the code does**  
1. Instead of reading from a file to get a cert, we read all the files in a given directory and add all the certs to the config.
2. Have a new method `Credentials::keycloak_by_json_string` that takes the json string as input. Also cache the json string so we don't need to read from files everytime when refreshing. 

**How to verify it**  
Tests should pass

candidates.title: Issue 223: Fix connection leak
candidates.body:
**Change log description**  
This PR adds a shutdown handle to PrefetchRead and prevents it from recycling connections.

The reason is that the background task of prefetching read could hang for a long time if the fetching offset is at the end of stream. If byte stream reader calls `seek`, then PrefetchRead will be destroyed and this background task is left unattended and a connection is leaked. 

However, adding shutdown hook itself is not enough. The connection could have stale message from the server when recycled back to pool. And anyone use that connection from the pool will have to deal with this stale message which is annoying. 

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #223

**What the code does**  
Adds a shutdown hook and prevents PrefetchRead from recycling connections.

**How to verify it**  
Manually verify that no connection leaked when calling `seek`.

candidates.title: Issue 192: Keycloak support
candidates.body:
**Change log description**  
Support keycloak

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #192 

**What the code does**  
If auth is enabled and keycloak is chosen, client will first try to read a `keycloak.json` file. After that Pravega Rust client will issue two POST requests to the keycloak server, the first POST request is to obtain an access token, so the Pravega Rust client can be authenticated and becomes a keycloak client. The second POST request is to use the access token to ask for permissions on behalf a user, which is the Rust client itself. The token returned from the second POST is called RPT(relying party token), with this token anyone can access to the given resources, which in our case, is just the Pravega controller. The RPT token is used by controller client in Rust client for authentication and authorization.

**How to verify it**  
Starts a SDP cluster and runs an application that uses the Pravega Rust client.
